stem_text: The reception of Hena Khan's book, Amina's Song, has been very good. Many reviewers, booksellers, and librarians have ______ the book, and it won the Asian/Pacific American Award for Literature.

choices.A: attacked
choices.B: overlooked
choices.C: recommended
choices.D: misunderstood

correct_answer.justification: Given the positive reception and the book winning an award, the most logical and precise choice is 'recommended.'

passage?.text: The reception of Hena Khan's book, Amina's Song, has been very good. Many reviewers, booksellers, and librarians have ______ the book, and it won the Asian/Pacific American Award for Literature.

stem_text: As used in the text, what does the word "conceivable" most nearly mean?

choices.A: Possible
choices.B: Regular
choices.C: Visible
choices.D: Basic

correct_answer.justification: "Conceivable" in this context means 'capable of being imagined or believed', which is best captured by the word 'possible'.

passage?.text:
The following text is adapted from Mary Seacole's 1857 autobiography Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands.
That journey across the Isthmus [of Panama], insignificant in distance as it was, was by no means an easy one. It seemed as if nature had determined to throw every conceivable obstacle in the way of those who should seek to join the two great oceans of the world.
passage?.source: Mary Seacole, Wonderful Adventures of Mrs. Seacole in Many Lands (1857)

stem_text: Kelp forests grow underwater along the eastern Pacific Coast. These underwater forests are important to fish and other marine animals. Ocean currents can be powerful and rough, making it difficult for animals to find safe places to hide from predators. The underwater forests slow down the currents. This creates a more ______ environment with calmer waters where animals can take shelter. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: surprising
choices.B: tranquil
choices.C: imaginative
choices.D: dangerous

correct_answer.justification: The passage describes how kelp forests slow down ocean currents and create calmer waters, which would result in a tranquil environment suitable for shelter.

passage?.text: Kelp forests grow underwater along the eastern Pacific Coast. These underwater forests are important to fish and other marine animals. Ocean currents can be powerful and rough, making it difficult for animals to find safe places to hide from predators. The underwater forests slow down the currents. This creates a more ______ environment with calmer waters where animals can take shelter.

stem_text:
The recently observed gamma ray burst GRB 230307A lasted for 200 seconds, __________ for a burst generated by the merger of neutron stars. Bursts caused by neutron mergers typically last fewer than 2 seconds.

Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: an incident
choices.B: a reprieve
choices.C: a coincidence
choices.D: an oddity

correct_answer.justification: The word 'oddity' best fits the context, describing the unusually long duration of a gamma ray burst generated by the merger of neutron stars.

passage?.text: The recently observed gamma ray burst GRB 230307A lasted for 200 seconds, __________ for a burst generated by the merger of neutron stars. Bursts caused by neutron mergers typically last fewer than 2 seconds.

stem_text: Which choice best describes the main purpose of the text?

choices.A: To call for additional research on biological mechanisms that improve pteropod survival rates
choices.B: To address some of the ways ocean acidification has altered pteropod behavior over time
choices.C: To discuss a causation drawn in a study of calcium carbonate’s role in protecting the periostracum of pteropods
choices.D: To present findings that suggest that a concern about the effects of ocean acidification on pteropod shells may be unwarranted

passage?.content: Pteropods are small swimming snails with thin, delicate calcium carbonate shells. These animals are thought to be especially vulnerable to ocean acidification due to calcium carbonate’s susceptibility to dissolution at lower pH values. Victoria Lisch and colleagues recently found that the periostracum (a protective coating on pteropods’ outer shells) prevents this dissolution when intact. Moreover, the team was surprised to discover that even when the periostracum is breached, pteropods can still mitigate damage by rebuilding the inner shell wall.

stem_text: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

choices.A: To describe the effect of high population density on any given city’s walkability
choices.B: To present a claim about how individuals’ decision-making about walking can be improved
choices.C: To discuss the difficulty of identifying a reliable way to increase walking in any given city
choices.D: To explain why it is challenging to compare the amount of pedestrian traffic in different cities

correct_answer.justification: The passage discusses why replicating a single feature of a walkable city may not reliably increase walking elsewhere, describing the complexity of decisions and contexts involved.

passage?.text: Tokyo has high pedestrian traffic, but simply replicating a feature of Tokyo associated with walkability—e.g., its high population density—may be insufficient to induce increased walking in other cities. As urbanist Isabella Alfonzo argues, our understanding of individual decision-making about whether to walk is unfinished; robust new studies emphasize the role of personal preferences, the role of perceived safety, and so on, but walking decisions are made in complex contexts in which multiple conditions and needs inform individuals’ choices.

stem_text: In the text, which point does Prospero most directly make about Miranda and her memories?

choices.A: Miranda’s impression of a scene is vague because she is remembering a scenario she had daydreamed about as a child rather than a scenario that had occurred in reality.
choices.B: Miranda’s doubts about the accuracy of one recollection of a place other than the island are clouding her judgment and cause her to be making her reluctant to explore the recollection of traveling to the island.
choices.C: Miranda’s reminiscences about her early childhood have a melancholy quality that betrays her discontented view of her current circumstances.
choices.D: Miranda’s ability to summon details of an experience she had before arriving on the island suggests that she may also be able to summon details of her arrival on the island.

correct_answer.justification: Prospero notes that if Miranda can remember events from before the island, she may also be able to remember how she came to the island.

passage?.text:
The following text is from William Shakespeare’s play The Tempest, first performed in 1611. Miranda has lived on an island with her father, Prospero, since she was three years old. Prospero has stated that Miranda likely does not remember anything other than her life on the island.

MIRANDA: ’Tis far off,
And rather like a dream than an assurance
That my remembrance warrants. Had I not
Four or five women once that tended me?

PROSPERO: Thou had’st, and more, Miranda. But how is it
That this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else
In the dark backward and abysm of time?
If thou remember’st aught ere thou camest here,
How thou camest here thou mayst.

stem_text: While researching other key industries in Oklahoma for an economics class, a student finds that the average amount contributed to the state’s economy in 2017 by each individual employed in wholesale trade was

correct_answer.justification: According to the table, the average contribution per employee by industry for wholesale trade is $111,730.

passage?.title: Impact of Four Key Industries on Oklahoma Economy in 2017
passage?.content:
Industry | Approximate total contribution to industry | Number of people employed by industry | Average contribution per employee by industry
Accommodations/food services | $5,821,100,000 | 153,573 | $37,913
Tribal economic activity | $2,921,800,000 | 51,974 | $56,310
Convention | $4,967,300,000 | 57,744 | $87,494
Wholesale trade | $6,073,240,000 | 54,346 | $111,730
The Muscogee Nation and the twenty-four other tribes in Oklahoma operate numerous businesses and collectively generate in the billions of dollars in revenue, helping to build and enrich jobs production, as every industry in the state as a whole.

stem_text: Which choice best describes data from the graph that support the student’s claim?

choices.A: In at least one of the three urban areas shown, the amount of traffic delay was less than 20 hours per commuter per year at some point between 1990 and 2000.
choices.B: In 1990, the amount of traffic delay in the New York City, New York, area was less than 50 hours per commuter per year.
choices.C: While the annual number of hours of traffic delay per commuter was always lower in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York area than in the New York City, New York area, during each year between 1990 and 2000, the amount of traffic delay rose in both areas during each time period.
choices.D: Even though the mean traffic of traffic delay per commuter per year was greater in the Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, area than in the New York City, New York, area, throughout the period from 1990 to 2000, the amounts were nearly identical in 1996.

passage?.text: In a college course on urban affairs, a student asserts that increased traffic congestion in the United States in the 1990s was present both in very large cities such as New York City, New York, and medium-size areas such as Albany-Schenectady-Troy, New York, and Beaumont, Texas. Though other smaller urban areas may have been affected by traffic congestion than very large cities, this congestion also worsened in them over time.

figures.description: Bar graph titled 'Annual Average Hours of Highway Traffic Delay per Auto Commuter,' showing years 1990, 1994, 1996, 1998, 2000, and three locations: New York City, Albany-Schenectady-Troy, and Beaumont.

stem_text: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the researchers' claim?

choices.A: Other insects like solitary bees also pollinate cucumber plants, and some studies have allowed them to pollinate normally while excluding honeybees.
choices.B: Other insects like squash bees also pollinate cucumber plants, and the shielding in the first phase of the study blocked them as well.
choices.C: Honeybees are more commonly used to pollinate cucumber plants than squash plants.
choices.D: The shielding used in the first phase of the study did not affect the amount of sunlight the cucumber plants received.

correct_answer.justification: The researchers claim that the first-phase experiment didn't indicate how much of the crop production difference is due specifically to honeybees. If other insects also pollinate cucumbers and the shielding blocked them as well, this supports the researchers' claim that the experiment doesn't isolate the effect of honeybees.

passage?.text: Past research suggests that pollination by honeybees is responsible for up to 10 percent of total cucumber crop production. Now researchers are trying to determine how dependent cucumber crop production is on honeybees. The first phase of their study involved shielding some cucumber plants to prevent insects from pollinating them, resulting in those plants having 80 to 90 percent lower crop production than plants that were pollinated normally. However, the researchers claim that the first-phase experiment alone didn't tell them how much of that difference in crop production is due specifically to excluding honeybees.

stem_text: In 1988, Arizona _______ official fossil: the Araucarioxylon arizonicum, which is a Triassic period tree.

choices.A: lawmakers designated the states
choices.B: lawmakers designated the state's
choices.C: lawmakers’ designated the state’s
choices.D: lawmakers designated the state's

correct_answer.justification: The correct possessive form for 'state' is 'state's', and no apostrophe is needed in 'lawmakers'.

passage?.text: In 1988, Arizona _______ official fossil: the Araucarioxylon arizonicum, which is a Triassic period tree.

stem_text:
Often anthologized alongside the _______ associated with the Black Arts movement—such as Gwendolyn Brooks and Jayne Cortez—bell hooks’s poem 'Appalachian Elegy (Section 1)' stands out for its memorable last lines: 'The covenant / between us / can never be broken / vows to live and let live.'

Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

choices.A: works of other writer’s
choices.B: works of other writers
choices.C: work’s of other writers
choices.D: works of other writers’

correct_answer.justification: The phrase 'works of other writers' does not require any apostrophes. 'Works' should be plural, and 'writers' also plural without possessive.

passage?.text: Often anthologized alongside the _______ associated with the Black Arts movement—such as Gwendolyn Brooks and Jayne Cortez—bell hooks’s poem 'Appalachian Elegy (Section 1)' stands out for its memorable last lines: 'The covenant / between us / can never be broken / vows to live and let live.'

stem_text:
Smartphones and other small electronic devices tend to use batteries that can’t be easily taken out and swapped for new ones. Environmental policy researcher Jean-Pierre Schweitzer warns that when these internal batteries stop working, the devices are usually thrown away, becoming harmful ______.

Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: advice
choices.B: waste
choices.C: rewards
choices.D: positions

correct_answer.justification: The context concerns discarded devices and the resulting harm, so 'waste' is the logical and precise word choice.

passage?.text: Smartphones and other small electronic devices tend to use batteries that can’t be easily taken out and swapped for new ones. Environmental policy researcher Jean-Pierre Schweitzer warns that when these internal batteries stop working, the devices are usually thrown away, becoming harmful ______.

stem_text: As used in the text, what does the word “delicate” most nearly mean?

choices.A: Generous
choices.B: Fragile
choices.C: Accurate
choices.D: Empty

correct_answer.justification: In the context of the passage, the snow is described as a 'gleaming carpet' that 'looked too delicate to be trodden upon by rough feet.' This suggests it is fragile or easily damaged.

passage?.source: The Wind in the Willows by Kenneth Grahame (1908)
passage?.text: The Mole saw the wood that had been so dreadful to him in quite a changed aspect. Holes, hollows, pools, pitfalls, and other menaces to the wayfarer were vanishing fast, and a gleaming carpet of snow was springing up everywhere, that looked too delicate to be trodden upon by rough feet.

stem_text:
Jean Batten, who was the first person to fly between England and New Zealand solo, and Ynes Mexia, who was the first to discover the botanical genus Mexianthus, are rewarded lasting places in our historical memory. No matter what others may do in the future, nobody can ever ________ the standing of these women as the first to accomplish these feats.

Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: undermine
choices.B: imply
choices.C: extend
choices.D: promote

correct_answer.justification: The correct word is 'undermine,' as it makes sense that nobody can ever undermine (weaken or diminish) the standing (reputation/achievement) of these women as the first to accomplish these feats.

passage?.excerpt: Jean Batten, who was the first person to fly between England and New Zealand solo, and Ynes Mexia, who was the first to discover the botanical genus Mexianthus, are rewarded lasting places in our historical memory. No matter what others may do in the future, nobody can ever ________ the standing of these women as the first to accomplish these feats.

stem_text: Whatever the general attitude toward Madeline Anderson’s 1970 film I Am Somebody and Reginald Hudlin’s 1990 film House Party when they were initially released, both films have tended to be regarded quite ________ in 2018, for example, critics for the New York Times praised the former as “galvanizing” and the latter as “exuberant.” Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: favorably
choices.B: skeptically
choices.C: neutrally
choices.D: strongly

correct_answer.justification: The context states that critics praised the films as 'galvanizing' and 'exuberant,' both positive terms, so the best fit is 'favorably.'

passage?.text: Whatever the general attitude toward Madeline Anderson’s 1970 film I Am Somebody and Reginald Hudlin’s 1990 film House Party when they were initially released, both films have tended to be regarded quite ________ in 2018, for example, critics for the New York Times praised the former as “galvanizing” and the latter as “exuberant.”

stem_text: To evaluate their ideas about environmental conditions in the Pliocene epoch, paleontologists must turn to ____ evidence. Only material objects—such as the fossil remains of the individual known as AL 288-1, discovered in Ethiopia in 1974—can show whether a particular idea about the Pliocene is defensible. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

choices.A: physical
choices.B: convenient
choices.C: creative
choices.D: inconclusive

correct_answer.justification: The passage states that only material objects can demonstrate whether a particular idea is defensible, making 'physical' the most precise word to describe the type of evidence referenced.

passage?.text: To evaluate their ideas about environmental conditions in the Pliocene epoch, paleontologists must turn to ____ evidence. Only material objects—such as the fossil remains of the individual known as AL 288-1, discovered in Ethiopia in 1974—can show whether a particular idea about the Pliocene is defensible.

stem_text: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined portion in the text as a whole?

choices.A: It illustrates the importance of an organization mentioned in the text.
choices.B: It compares the achievements of two people discussed later in the text.
choices.C: It argues against the claim made earlier in the text.
choices.D: It provides additional information about a person discussed in the text.

passage?.text: Joseph A. Walker’s award-winning play The River Niger was produced in 1972 by the groundbreaking Negro Ensemble Company (NEC). NEC cofounder Douglas Turner Ward, who trained as an actor, director, and playwright, had met actor and producer Robert Hooks while they were performing in a 1960 touring production of Lorraine Hansberry’s play A Raisin in the Sun. Together, they envisioned a theater company that would nurture and showcase the work of Black theater professionals. Since NEC’s founding in 1967, its workshops and performances have given Black playwrights, including Walker, a forum for their compelling stories.

stem_text: Which choice best describes the function of the reference to "heavy reliance on visual foraging" in the text as a whole?

choices.A: It emphasizes an attribute of Mohol bushbabies that enables them to respond to lunar intensity variations more rapidly than greater Egyptian gerbils and many other nocturnal mammals do.
choices.B: It identifies a characteristic of Mohol bushbabies that explains why they do not reduce their activity under high lunar intensity like greater Egyptian gerbils and many other nocturnal mammals do.
choices.C: It describes a behavioral pattern displayed by Mohol bushbabies that is inconsistent with how they would be expected to respond to high lunar intensity based on benefits and costs.
choices.D: It presents a trait of Mohol bushbabies that serves as evidence for the assertion that greater Egyptian gerbils are not the only nocturnal mammals whose activity is inhibited by high lunar intensity.

correct_answer.justification: The passage explains that unlike gerbils, Mohol bushbabies rely heavily on visual foraging, which results in a different balance of reward and risk and explains their different response to moonlight.

passage?.text: Burt Kotler and colleagues showed that high moonlight intensity inhibits the activity of the greater Egyptian gerbil (Gerbillus pyramidum), a finding explicable in terms of benefits and costs: greater moon intensity may not enable the gerbils to increase foraging success enough to offset the higher chance of detection by predatory foxes or owls. Though many other nocturnal mammals respond to lunar intensity variations similarly to greater Egyptian gerbils, Mohol bushbabies (Galago moholi) display the opposite pattern, as their heavy reliance on visual foraging results in a different balance of reward and risk.

stem_text: Based on the texts, how would the author of Text 2 most likely respond to the description of Asimov's characters in the underlined portion of Text 1?

choices.A: Asimov's characterizations would have been richer if he had possessed a deeper understanding of history.
choices.B: The flatness of Asimov's characters is a feature of The Caves of Steel and The Stars, Like Dust but not of Foundation.
choices.C: The flatness of Asimov's characters should not necessarily be considered a flaw in his writing.
choices.D: Asimov's characterizations would have been more believable if his writing had discussed fewer ideas.

correct_answer.justification: Text 2 argues that it is misguided to fault Asimov for his characterization, as it serves his thematic purpose. This aligns most closely with Choice C.

passage?.main_passage:
Text 1
Isaac Asimov, author of The Caves of Steel and The Stars, Like Dust, is highly regarded despite his mediocre writing style. His prose is workmanlike; his characters are flat and discuss ideas rather than emotions. That his work is enjoyable despite this is a testament to his prodigious imagination—even if people read his books solely for the ideas, they will have plenty to consider.

Text 2
Asimov is criticized for his style, but it is wrong to fault a writer for failing to do what he never intended to do. For example, although most of his novel Foundation consists of people discussing science and politics and we find out little about his characters’ lives, Asimov wanted to convey the vast sweep of human history over centuries, and one of his points is that at such a timescale, individuals don’t matter. Thus his lack of characterization is central to this thematic aim.

stem_text: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

choices.A: Animals find it difficult to use objects as tools.
choices.B: Unlike primates, sea otters are exceptionally skillful at using different tools.
choices.C: Contrary to long-held beliefs, primates aren’t the only animals to use tools.
choices.D: There are many myths about tool use that researchers are starting to challenge.

correct_answer.justification: The passage explains that many animals besides primates, such as sea otters and woodpecker finches, use tools, showing that tool use is not unique to primates.

passage?.text: Animals use many objects as tools to achieve goals more easily. Such goals include grooming, finding food, and protecting themselves. For a long time, people thought tool use was unique to primates. Sea otters and other animals, though, have busted the myth that tool use is limited to certain primates. Invertebrates, sea otters use stationary await stones to break open mollusk shells. Woodpecker finches also get creative. They use cactus spines to pry insects from hiding places.

stem_text: A student is writing a paper on the global rise of the home video game industry during the 1980s. The student wants to know the release year of the video game Zelda II: The Adventure of Link, developed by Nintendo EAD. The student finds that this game was released in ______. Which choice most effectively uses data from the table to complete the statement?

correct_answer.justification: According to the table, 'Zelda II: The Adventure of Link' was released in 1987.

passage?.content:
Home Video Games and Computer Games of the 1980s

| Title                       | Approximate number of units sold worldwide | Release year | Genre              | Developer      |
|-----------------------------|--------------------------------------------|--------------|--------------------|---------------|
| ExciteBike                  | 4,160,000                                  | 1984         | racing             | Nintendo R&D1  |
| The Last Ninja 2            | 5,000,000                                  | 1988         | action-adventure   | System 3       |
| Zelda II: The Adventure of Link | 4,380,000                              | 1987         | action-adventure   | Nintendo EAD   |
| Frogger                     | 4,100,000                                  | 1982         | action             | Konami         |

figures.description: A table listing home video games and computer games of the 1980s, including columns for Title, Approximate number of units sold worldwide, Release year, Genre, and Developer.

stem_text: Which finding, if true, would most directly support the student's claim?

choices.A: The 12th episode of Clancy of the Mounted was the most expansive episode of the series to produce.
choices.B: The 12th episode of Clancy of the Mounted was viewed by more people than was any previous episode in the series.
choices.C: Modern critics generally regard the first episode as the best installment of Clancy of the Mounted.
choices.D: Audiences of the time considered Clancy of the Mounted to belong to a genre other than the northern adventure genre.

correct_answer.justification: If the 12th episode, which presumably provided resolution and closure to the story, was the most viewed, this directly supports the claim that audiences preferred resolution and closure over ongoing tension.

passage?.text: A film studies student is researching early 20th-century film serials, which consisted of individual episodes of a single story that were shown weekly in theaters. Clancy of the Mounted is a 1933 serial, and there are 12 episodes. It kept its audience interested with the suspense and drama that are typical of the northern adventure genre. The student, however, claims that audiences of the time preferred resolution and closure over ongoing tension.

stem_text: Which quotation from Treasure Island most effectively illustrates the claim that the narrator was frightened of the sailor?

choices.A: "How that person haunted my dreams, I need scarcely tell you. On stormy nights, when the wind shook the four corners of the house and the surf roared along the cove and up the cliffs, I would see him in a thousand forms, and with a thousand diabolical expressions."
choices.B: "I remember the sailor as if it were yesterday, as he came plodding to the inn door, his sea-chest following behind him in a hand-barrow."
choices.C: "The sailor was a very silent man by custom. All day he hung round the cove or upon the cliffs with a brass telescope."
choices.D: "All the time he lived with us the squire made no change whatever in his dress but to buy some stockings from a hawker. One of the [corners] of his hat, having fallen down, he let it hang from that day forth, though it was a great annoyance when it blew."

correct_answer.justification: Choice A shows the narrator being haunted and frightened by the sailor, which directly illustrates the claim.

passage?.text: Treasure Island is an 1883 novel by Robert Louis Stevenson. When the narrator was a child, his father ran a hotel. A mysterious sailor came to stay at the hotel. The narrator was frightened of the sailor, as can be seen when the narrator says _____.

stem_text: Which finding, if true, would most directly weaken the students’ conclusion?

choices.A: Some wild-type mice were very similar to the knockout mice with respect to cataract frequency but showed a wide variety of levels of expression of Asah1.
choices.B: The level of expression of Asah1 does not appear to affect the functioning of any other genes in house mice.
choices.C: A sample of house mice captured in natural settings shows that individual mice can differ from one another in the level of expression of Asah1.
choices.D: The mice with Asah1 deactivated were identical to the wild-type mice except with regard to cataract frequency.

correct_answer.justification: If some wild-type mice have varying levels of Asah1 expression but similar cataract frequencies to knockout mice, it suggests that factors besides Asah1 expression contribute to cataract susceptibility, directly weakening the conclusion.

passage?.text: Students in a biology class investigated why individual house mice (Mus musculus) can differ from one another in their susceptibility to cataracts in old age. The students compared wild-type mice and knockout mice, which are mice with specific genes deactivated, when mice of each type were raised in similar naturalistic environments and periodically tested for cataracts. Finding that knockout mice with the gene Asah1 deactivated tended to develop cataracts more frequently than wild-type mice, the students concluded that differences in cataract frequency among house mice in nature are solely attributable to variations in the level of expression of Asah1.

stem_text: Marine biologist Kristin Laidre disagrees with that idea, though. She reasons that if the narwhal’s tusk serves such an important purpose, then it’s most likely that

choices.A: some narwhals would seek a new habitat.
choices.B: more narwhals would have a tusk.
choices.C: fewer marine animals would also have tusks.
choices.D: narwhals would become less shy over time.

correct_answer.justification: The argument is that if the tusk served an important survival function, more narwhals would have evolved to have one.

passage?.text: Narwhals are shy whales that live in the remote Arctic Ocean. Some of them have a long tusk, like a unicorn horn, with sensitive nerves. Narwhals are known for this tusk, but many actually don’t have one and its purpose is unknown. One group of scientists came up with a possible purpose in 2014: the scientists suggested that the tusk may help narwhals determine when venturing under ice is likely to entail trapping and become dangerous for them. Marine biologist Kristin Laidre disagrees with that idea, though. She reasons that if the narwhal’s tusk serves such an important purpose, then it’s most likely that

stem_text: Over 600 languages are spoken in New York City. In addition to English—one can find Bengali speakers in the neighborhood of Yorkville, or Chale in Jackson Heights. Most speakers of Chinese languages reside in the neighborhood of Flushing (part of New York City’s borough of Queens) and in Chinatown, in the borough of Manhattan. New immigrants from north China, where Mandarin is the primary first language, tend to settle in Queens, while new immigrants from south China, where many people speak Cantonese or Fuzhouese as a first language, tend to settle in Manhattan. It can therefore be inferred that Which choice most logically completes the text?

choices.A: languages tend to change more rapidly in areas where many languages are spoken than in areas where few languages are spoken.
choices.B: operationalism in country between two languages and regions where they are common is representative when in a new country to which the original country’s citizens emigrate.
choices.C: languages spoken by immigrant peoples can differ significantly in vocabulary and pronunciation from those same languages in their country of origin.
choices.D: there is a positive correlation between the physical size of a country and the number of languages spoken in that country.

stem_text: F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1920 novel This Side of Paradise contains elements drawn from Fitzgerald’s own life—there are many parallels between the experiences of the novel’s protagonist, Amory Blaine, and those of Fitzgerald—and as a result This Side of Paradise is regularly described as an autobiographical work. This characterization can be useful, but it also presents drawbacks in terms of how the work is perceived, as it may lead readers to believe that Fitzgerald merely fictionalized true events, which, in an artistic field where creativity and inventiveness are prized, can suggest that

choices.A: This Side of Paradise is less of an imaginative achievement than it actually is.
choices.B: Fitzgerald should not have claimed that This Side of Paradise is based on real events.
choices.C: critics disagree about whether This Side of Paradise shows greater originality than works without autobiographical elements.
choices.D: the real-world counterparts of other characters in This Side of Paradise are hard to identify.

correct_answer.justification: The sentence addresses how autobiographical characterization may impact perception by suggesting it diminishes the work's imaginative status. Choice A completes the sentence in a way that logically follows from the information provided.

passage?.text: F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1920 novel This Side of Paradise contains elements drawn from Fitzgerald’s own life—there are many parallels between the experiences of the novel’s protagonist, Amory Blaine, and those of Fitzgerald—and as a result This Side of Paradise is regularly described as an autobiographical work. This characterization can be useful, but it also presents drawbacks in terms of how the work is perceived, as it may lead readers to believe that Fitzgerald merely fictionalized true events, which, in an artistic field where creativity and inventiveness are prized, can suggest that
